position.marginalia_text: Maximè sapit, qui prouidet maximè, vt à Seipso dependeat:
quantu[m] facere potest vllo modo. Summa summaru[m] Epicteti, Seneca[e], Antonini. Quomodò Crates; nihilo egere philosophum. Stoici; Omnia esse Sapientum.
μόνος ὁ σοφὸς πλούσιος. ὅτι ἀυταρκὴς ἡ ἀρετὴ πρὸς ἐυδαιμονϊαν.

X-ref.text: ὅτι ἀυταρκὴς ἡ ἀρετὴ πρὸς ἐυδαιμονϊαν

marginalia.translation: He who takes care the most that he depend only on himself is he who knows the most. And he can do as much as possible in any way. The sum of sums of Epictetus, of Seneca, of Marus Aurelius. Crates in the same manner -- that the philosopher needs nothing. Of the Stoic: that the wise man is all things. That only the wise man is rich. That virtue is self-sufficient for happiness.

position.marginalia_text: Omnes Magistros superat profundus discipulus. Puer est, qui nondum didicit viuere.

marginalia.translation: The profound disciple surpasses all magistrates. He who has not yet learned to live is a child.

position.marginalia_text: Sera nimis sophia est crastina; disce hodiè.

marginalia.translation: Tomorrow's wisdom is too late; learn today.

position.marginalia_text: ὅτι σοφὸι ἐλεύθεροι, καὶ ὁι μωρὸι δοῦλοι.

X-ref.text: ὅτι σοφὸι ἐλεύθεροι, καὶ ὁι μωρὸι δοῦλοι

marginalia.translation: That all wise men are free, and all fools are slaves.

position.marginalia_text: Crastinia sera nimis copia: cresce hodiè.

marginalia.translation: Tomorrow's bounty is too late; grow today.
